Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I stood in the crowded polling station, clutching my ID, my heart pounding. The election official explained, apologetically, that my name didn’t match the registration list exactly. If I wanted my vote to count, I’d have to fill out a provisional ballot form—right now, before the station closed in ten minutes. My phone buzzed with a message from my mother: “Don’t forget, come straight home after voting. We’re lighting the family candles at sunset, just like every year.” This tradition was sacred in our house, a symbol of everything my parents believed in. They’d been reminding me all week how important it was to be there on time, to show respect for our heritage. But the form was long, and the line was slow. If I stayed, I’d miss the ceremony. If I left, my vote wouldn’t count. I felt torn in two, the weight of my family’s expectations pressing on one side, my duty as a citizen on the other. My hands shook as I stared at the form, the clock ticking louder in my ears, caught between honoring my family and fulfilling my responsibility as a voter.
